utterance: Tom Mansell: Sensing and regulation is a big part of the plan here. But for now, we're in the very preliminary stages of that.

utterance: Tanya Nguyen: To follow up on what you're saying and also what Jay had mentioned earlier, and I have no idea how to do this, but it would be so cool to develop a way to kind of individually determine what someone's microbiome is at homeostasis, their ideal kind of microbiome environment, whether that be composition, metabolites, chemicals, and then use that as a baseline, and then being able to develop, you know, these different chemically engineered bacteria then produce specific metabolites to keep that person at that specific ideal level or attain an ideal level for them to then minimize their clinical symptoms or functioning. I think that would be a really cool idea, no idea how to get there, but happy to talk about it further and develop that.

Idea Management.explanation: Tanya introduces a novel and highly elaborated idea about individually determining microbiome homeostasis and developing engineered bacteria to maintain it, building on previous discussions.
Idea Management.score_justification: The idea is highly detailed, novel, and builds on prior contributions, proposing a complex and forward-thinking research direction.

utterance: Tom Mansell: I think you could do it with one molecule. I don't know about all of those. But you know, if it's short chain fatty acids, I think that that's a great idea.

Evaluation Practices.explanation: Tom assesses the merit and feasibility of Tanya's idea by explicitly stating 'I think that that's a great idea' for a specific scope ('short chain fatty acids') while implicitly critiquing the broader scope ('I don't know about all of those').
Evaluation Practices.score_justification: Tom provides constructive and reasoned feedback by supporting a specific aspect of the idea and suggesting a more feasible, actionable scope.

utterance: Tom Mansell: I just have to say, as a chemical engineer, the thing that I have gotten most out of this discussion is this motility concept, right? utterance: Tom Mansell: A key parameter of reactor design is residence time, which is the flow rate divided by the volume, right? So, that motility, being the flow rate, is going to influence the conversion or whatever fermentation products come out of your reactor, right? And so, I love this idea of influencing motility as a way to manipulate the microbiome, and in doing so, manipulate the metabolome.

Idea Management.explanation: Tom elaborates on the idea of influencing motility to manipulate the microbiome and metabolome by connecting it to the engineering concept of reactor design and residence time.
Idea Management.score_justification: This is a novel, elaborated, and reasoned idea, building on the 'motility concept' and providing a mechanism (residence time/flow rate) for manipulation, moving the team forward.

Knowledge Sharing.explanation: Tom shares his expertise as a chemical engineer by explaining the concept of residence time in reactor design and applying it to the discussion of motility and the microbiome.
Knowledge Sharing.score_justification: This is accurate, detailed, and directly useful knowledge, connecting an engineering concept to the biological problem at hand.

Relational Climate.explanation: Tom expresses strong enthusiasm for the idea of influencing motility as a way to manipulate the microbiome and metabolome by stating 'I love this idea.'
Relational Climate.score_justification: This strong expression of enthusiasm fosters curiosity and a positive climate within the discussion.
